author: potuz
content: In <@273808422753796097> proposal for the cap and rotation of validators. What's an argument against paying full attestation rewards to the sleeping validators? We can lower `base_reward` accordingly so that the overall issuance stays the same. But by paying the dormant validators no one will complain by being dormant and while active we still have encouragement to attest correctly. At the same time, there's no incentive on active validators to delay finality or any bad play to stay active, since being dormant is better

author: .vbuterin
content: Hmm that's definitely an option, though it would reduce the incentive to do a good job validating

author: potuz
content: I don't see why since while you're active you'll still be penalized for not doing your job. This way you only get penalized for not doing your job

author: potuz
content: Of course if numbers are inverted and we're talking about 15M validators, of which only 500K are active, the situation might be different

author: pietjepuk
content: (iirc we talking about this before over in the ethstaker discord) Not sure if this would work (integer math and all), but I think it would be nice if the APR decrease with more validators stays more or less the same as it would without the cap. So if paying sleeping validators is not allowed (which would accomplish this I think), maybe multiply the base reward with `1 + fraction_sleeping` when someone _does_ make an attestation?

author: potuz
content: Yes I was there in that discussion but I don't recall a suggestion to pay sleeping validators. I was thinking about this and can't really come up with a good argument against and have a few in favor of paying.

author: .vbuterin
content: Oh to be clear sleeping validators *definitely* get no penalties

author: potuz
content: Sure

author: potuz
content: But they get no rewards which is a penalty in the mind of the validator

author: pietjepuk
content: One thing in favor e.g. keeping the total rewards fixed if we go over the cap is that staked ETH that is not active does not contribute to security (right?). This would be different for ETH up to the cap, so there's something to be said to have a discontinuous derivative of `eth_staked -> base_reward`.

author: potuz
content: That derivative becomes discontinuous only if `eth_staked` is used as opposed to effective balance of all validators. But yes this is semantics. An actual point is that I would consider all validators actively supporting the network, even the dormant ones since you do not know if your validator becomes active in an epoch so you still need to be running nonetheless. To bring this to an extreme: all those validators that are not attesting in slot N, are they supporting the network or not? I'd say they are, and now are in an idle state waiting for their duties

author: .vbuterin
content: > staked ETH that is not active does not contribute to security (right?).

author: .vbuterin
content: The answer to this question is actually kinda subtle

author: .vbuterin
content: It depends on your security model

author: .vbuterin
content: So for example, suppose that the cap is 10M ETH but actually there's 80M ETH staking

author: .vbuterin
content: The amount of ETH that needs to get _slashed_ for a double-finality event to happen is ~3M

author: .vbuterin
content: But the amount of staked ETH that the attacker _needs to have access to_ is ~27M

author: .vbuterin
content: Because the awake validators are effectively a randomly sampled committee

author: .vbuterin
content: Right, this is actually a really good point

author: .vbuterin
content: But I don't see why we need payment to line up perfectly with service to the network

author: .vbuterin
content: They already line up approximately, and after 2-4 months the effect of "luck" from how often you're awake will be close to negligible

author: .vbuterin
content: (and in fact, my proposal 2 in the doc actually makes the luck even less of a problem, because everyone gets a slice of the same length)
